sect1.title: IP Basics
sect1.para: You can change the hostname and domain used by your firewall in the General Setup screen.

sect1.title: NAT
sect1.para: NAT (Network Address Translation) permits you to use private IP address space on your LAN while still being able to access the internet.
There are two main types of NAT in m0n0wall, inbound, and 1:1.

sect1.title: DNS
sect1.para: You can change the DNS servers used by your firewall in the General Setup screen.

sect1.title: Logging (syslog)
sect1.para: It is recommended that you log your m0n0wall to a remote syslog server for diagnostics and forensic purposes. There are a number of free tools receive and store syslog messages for you on Windows, Mac, and Unix based systems. These software packages also offer additional features such as automatically sending pages, emails or SMS messages as well as running software or commands based on the messages that are received.

tip.para: Log messages include a timestamp of when the event ocurred. The system time on the firewall is synchronized to an NTP (Network Time Protocol) server. You can change the NTP server and related parameters in the General Setup screen.

sect1.para: The syslog daemon built into virtually every Unix-like system can be configured to accept log messages from remote hosts. Check documentation specific to your OS on how to configure syslogd to accept messages from remote hosts.
There are several free and commercial tools available on Windows to enable your system to accept syslog messages from hosts on your network.

One of my favorites on Windows is Kiwi Syslog. There is a version with "basic" features that is free, and a more advanced version with $49 registration. Even if you are just looking for a free tool, the basic version has as many if not more features than any other free package on this list. http://www.kiwi-enterprises.com/

3Com offers a couple of free utilities on this page. 3CSyslog is a GUI tool best used on a temporary or as-needed basis only. To collect logs using a service that will be running at all times, whether or not anyone is logged into the machine, try wsyslogd.
Several more for Windows and a couple for Mac listed on this site.
